Hey Jeff,
> But we already know the result of that experiment. Ken has show=
n that
target-based evolution doesn't work, so the error for target-based
e=
volution will be non-zero (and likely large). But (as we mention in the
pap=
er) the error in our method can be tuned toward zero by increasing
the reso=
lution of the workspace, so the error for the Seeded-CPPN
technique effecti=
vely is zero. Thus, we know ahead of time that our
method won't produce err=
or. The only uncertainty is how bad target based
evolution would be, but th=
at is not the focus of this paper, so the
experiment would be off-topic. In=
 other words, we introduce a technique
that eliminates the issue of error, =
since it skips right to the correct
shape=85to compare it against an obviou=
sly bad technique that we know
produces error would only be to satisfy revi=
ewers that insist on
quantification; it does not address a broader hypothes=
is, no?

Sure, but those statements are a bit "cowboy science-y." Let me sh=
ow you
how those statements can (and likely will) be translated:
"A single =
(non-reproduced?) study has suggested that targeted evolution
does not work=
 very well (with Picbreeder?). Our method can achieve an
error of zero (dat=
a not shown). Thus, comparing our method with targeted
evolution is pointle=
ss."
Performing such a quantitative comparison would kill two birds with on=
e
stone: (1) it reproduces the findings that Ken made* in a 3D domain, and
=
(2) it would address the readers' concerns related to the goal of the
paper=
, particularly by directly showing that your method produces more
accurate =
CPPN-based representations of 3D objects than the "leading"
(only) method. =
For a methods paper, that is an important statement to
make. Thus, there is=
 value in making a quantitative comparison here, and
it's not an arbitrary =
checkbox.
* I'm not suggesting that Ken did/does bad or unreliable work, bu=
t
reproducing results that you're building off of is an important part of
s=
cience -- especially when you're applying those results in a new domain
(2D=
 objects vs. 3D objects).


> Any paper would be stronger if it also did it=
s Future Work section. In
fact, a lot of the reviewers were upset that so m=
uch time in the paper
was spent discussing the future work that this techni=
que enables. But I
believe that's often precisely what makes new techniques=
 interesting:
the possibilities they enable.  There is always a tension bet=
ween doing
the future work, or just mentioning that it can be done. For a
c=
onference paper, I think it is fine to publish a smaller package of
work an=
d point to future possible work.
It's a really bad assumption (that many of=
 us make) that someone will
want to follow up on our work. Yes, it's good t=
o point out future
research directions from the work, but the mindset that =
everyone will
want to follow up on our work can be damaging to the research=
 field.
Everyone wants to be the thought leader and establish a "new" resea=
rch
path, and that's why we see so many people establishing new research
pl=
atforms and whatnot every year and talking about all the cool research
that=
 it enables. Then by the next year, that platform has fallen into
obscurity=
 because no one wanted to actually do that future work, and
thus no one rea=
lly learned anything from the paper introducing that
research platform.
Tha=
t's a big reason why I think qualitative/methods/proof of concept 
papers (=
whatever you want to call them -- they're the same) are not very
useful to =
publish as full papers, and are better suited as a poster or
late-breaking =
abstract.

> I'm sorry we didn't make it clear to you. Of course, that issu=
e is
also orthogonal to the quantitative vs. qualitative conversation, but =
it
is something I would like to address. Can you tell me what questions you=

have? I'd be happy to try to answer them in this thread. If anyone
reading=
 this also has questions about the technique, please let me know.

I think =
my main confusion is the significance of the ds input to the
CPPN. How does=
 the CPPN end up using that input? Why is that input
useful for training a =
CPPN to reproduce a predetermined 3D object?

Cheers, Randy

Hey Jeff,<div><div><br></div><div> > But we already know the result of =
that experiment. Ken has shown that target-based evolution doesn't work, so=
 the error for target-based evolution will be non-zero (and likely large). =
But (as we mention in the paper) the error in our method can be tuned towar=
d zero by increasing the resolution of the workspace, so the error for the =
Seeded-CPPN technique effectively is zero. Thus, we know ahead of time that=
 our method won't produce error. The only uncertainty is how bad target bas=
ed evolution would be, but that is not the focus of this paper, so the expe=
riment would be off-topic. In other words, we introduce a technique that el=
iminates the issue of error, since it skips right to the correct shape=85to=
 compare it against an obviously bad technique that we know produces error =
would only be to satisfy reviewers that insist on quantification; it does n=
ot address a broader hypothesis, no?<br><br>Sure, but those statements are =
a bit "cowboy science-y." Let me show you how those statements ca=
n (and likely will) be translated:</div><div><br></div><div> "A single=
 (non-reproduced?) study has suggested that targeted evolution does not wor=
k very well (with Picbreeder?). Our method can achieve an error of zero (da=
ta not shown). Thus, comparing our method with targeted evolution is pointl=
ess."</div><div><br></div><div> Performing such a quantitative compari=
son would kill two birds with one stone: (1) it reproduces the findings tha=
t Ken made* in a 3D domain, and (2) it would address the readers' concerns =
related to the goal of the paper, particularly by directly showing that you=
r method produces more accurate CPPN-based representations of 3D objects th=
an the "leading" (only) method. For a methods paper, that is an i=
mportant statement to make. Thus, there is value in making a quantitative c=
omparison here, and it's not an arbitrary checkbox.</div><div><br></div><di=
v> * I'm not suggesting that Ken did/does bad or unreliable work, but repro=
ducing results that you're building off of is an important part of science =
-- especially when you're applying those results in a new domain (2D object=
s vs. 3D objects).<br><br><br>> Any paper would be stronger if it also d=
id its Future Work section. In fact, a lot of the reviewers were upset that=
 so much time in the paper was spent discussing the future work that this t=
echnique enables. But I believe that's often precisely what makes new techn=
iques interesting: the possibilities they enable.  There is always a t=
ension between doing the future work, or just mentioning that it can be don=
e. For a conference paper, I think it is fine to publish a smaller package =
of work and point to future possible work.</div><div><br></div><div> It's a=
 <i>really</i> bad assumption (that many of us make) that someone will want=
 to follow up on our work. Yes, it's good to point out future research dire=
ctions from the work, but the mindset that everyone will want to follow up =
on our work can be damaging to the research field. Everyone wants to be the=
 thought leader and establish a "new" research path, and that's w=
hy we see so many people establishing new research platforms and whatnot ev=
ery year and talking about all the cool research that it enables. Then by t=
he next year, that platform has fallen into obscurity because no one wanted=
 to actually do that future work, and thus no one really learned anything f=
rom the paper introducing that research platform.</div><div><br></div><div>=
 That's a big reason why I think qualitative/methods/proof of concept =
 papers (whatever you want to call them -- they're the same) are not very u=
seful to publish as full papers, and are better suited as a poster or late-=
breaking abstract.</div><div><br></div><div><br>> I'm sorry we didn't ma=
ke it clear to you. Of course, that issue is also orthogonal to the quantit=
ative vs. qualitative conversation, but it is something I would like to add=
ress. Can you tell me what questions you have? I'd be happy to try to answe=
r them in this thread. If anyone reading this also has questions about the =
technique, please let me know. <br><br>
</div><div> I think my main confusi=
on is the significance of the ds input to the CPPN. How does the CPPN end u=
p using that input? Why is that input useful for training a CPPN to reprodu=
ce a predetermined 3D object?</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div> Chee=
rs,</div><div> Randy</div></div>
